docs.title: plasma_current
docs.text:
• units: A

  • tags: equilibrium, current, mhd, plasma

Plasma current is the total electric current flowing within a magnetically confined plasma, primarily in the toroidal direction. It represents the integrated toroidal current density over the plasma cross-section and is a fundamental parameter in magnetic confinement fusion devices.

The mathematical definition of plasma current is:

\[I_p = \iint j_\phi \, dA\]

where \(I_p\) is the plasma current, \(j_\phi\) is the toroidal component of the current density (A/m²), and the integration is performed over the entire poloidal cross-section of the plasma.

In axisymmetric tokamaks, the plasma current flows primarily in the toroidal direction and creates a poloidal magnetic field component that is essential for plasma confinement. The sign convention for plasma current is that a positive value indicates current flowing in the counter-clockwise direction when viewed from above the torus.

The plasma current serves several critical functions in fusion plasmas:

  • It generates the poloidal component of the magnetic field necessary for plasma equilibrium
  • It drives ohmic heating through resistive dissipation
  • It affects plasma stability by modifying the safety factor profile
  • It influences plasma confinement through its effect on the magnetic configuration

In stellarators, which rely primarily on external coils for confinement, the plasma current is typically much smaller but still plays a role in the overall plasma behavior and equilibrium.

The plasma current can be driven by several mechanisms:

  • Inductive current drive (transformer action)
  • Non-inductive current drive methods such as:
  • Neutral beam injection (NBI)
  • Radio-frequency waves
  • Bootstrap current (self-generated by plasma pressure gradients)
